comment.author: 22215670@N00
comment._content:
The picture is incredible. I have studied it at it's original size and every detail offers a different impression of what life was like. So much information preserved in sepia.
I have seen nothing like it in moving pictures and can only imagine than no one would believe it if you recreated it for film.

I feel fortunate to have been able to see this. Thank you.

comment.author: 27004610@N05
comment._content: This photo caught my attention because it looks close to home for me. Curtis was on our shores and took many photos of our first nations on the west coast of Vancouver Island, Canada. Some of his work is in local museums. I am intrigued by the word 'Qagyuhl' on the bottom-left side of the image. I wonder if it's his spelling for Kwaguilth, our northern neighbours.

comment.author: 7576993@N07
comment._content:
Hello Mrs. Titian, 

According to the Handbook of North American Indians, vol. 7, Northwest Coast, page 376, Qagyuhl was an early spelling of the term now known as Kwakiutl.
